awd_titl_txt: Optimized coordination and scheduling of traffic evolving on complex guidepath networks
awd_abstract_narration:
In many contemporary industrial and distribution applications, the material handling operations are executed automatically by fleet of robotized agents (e.g., mobile robots, vehicles circulating on elevated monorail systems, or complex arrays of gantry cranes) circulating over a guidepath network that is defined either by the physical structure of the material handling system (as in the case of the monorail and the gantry crane systems), or defined externally in an effort to separate the corresponding traffic from the surrounding environment. As these material handling systems increase in scale and operational complexity, there is an emergent need for a more systematic methodology that will support expedient and safe traffic for the traveling agents, while taking into consideration all the constraints and limitations that arise from the constricted nature of the underlying guidepath network and of the limited maneuvering capabilities of the agents themselves. Furthermore, similar traffic dynamics and control needs arise in the operational context of quantum computing systems. In that case, the ionized atoms (or qubits) that carry the elementary information to be processed in those systems, must be transported to different locations in order to interact with each other or with certain external fields, and this transport must be performed through a network of carefully defined and allocated tunnels (more formally known as ion traps); these tunnels and the corresponding allocation of them to the traveling qubits intends to protect the processed information by isolating the qubits from their surrounding environment and preventing unintended interaction among them. The successful completion of the proposed research program will develop a complete methodology for effective and efficient real-time coordination and scheduling of the traffic that takes place in the aforementioned application environments. In particular, the expected results will enable safe, orderly and expedient traveling for the system agents in the face of all the complexity of the underlying operations, which will further lead to higher levels of flexibility, robustness and productivity for these operations. Furthermore, the project will employ a graduate student who will carry out a Ph.D. thesis on the proposed set of problems, and the obtained results will be implemented on a high-fidelity simulator of a quantum computer that is developed by a group of researchers at the Georgia Tech Research Institute and have an active collaboration with the PI and the aforementioned graduate student. In addition, the PI will leverage his affiliation with the College-Industry Council on Material Handling Education in order to promote the obtained results to the relevant material handling industries.

To effectively meet the research objectives outlined in the previous paragraph, the proposed research program will substantially complement and extend the current theory on the real-time coordination and scheduling of complex traffic systems. In the proposed modeling and analysis paradigm, the considered traffic management problems will be represented as sequential resource allocation problems where the running processes are the trips executed by the system agents, and the allocated resources are the various segments of the guidepath network that are needed for the execution of these trips. This allocation must be controlled for logical correctness, that in the considered problem context translates to the establishment of safety and liveness for the underlying traffic, and also for expediency, which translates to delay minimization and high throughput for the requested transports. All these requirements will be met through the employment, extension and integration of ideas and results coming from the areas of (i) logical control of complex resource allocation systems, (ii) (combinatorial) scheduling theory, and (iii) the embedding of these results in a novel model predictive control framework.

por.por_cntn:
Many contemporary technological applications involve the management of traffic that evolves in constricted and congested environments. Some specific examples include (i) the traffic that takes place in automated material handling systems in modern production and warehousing facilities, (ii) the subway systems that have been deployed in many urban areas around the world and the monorail systems that are used in most major airports, and even (iii) the traffic of the ionized atoms (also known as ?qubits?) that constitute the elementary information careers in the context of quantum computing. 

In all the aforementioned environments, the generated traffic must be controlled for expediency and time-based efficiency, but an additional important concern is the avoidance of problematic situations of a more qualitative nature, especially the formation of deadlocks and livelocks among the traveling agents. This additional class of problems is more formally known as the preservation of liveness in the considered traffic systems, and it becomes particularly prevalent when the traveling entities are some mechanical devices or other physical entities of preprogrammed intelligence, as is the case with various classes of mobile robots, drones and other autonomous vehicles.

The resulting control problem of establishing live and expedient traffic in the context of the aforementioned applications is very complex, both, analytically and computationally. Therefore, there is a need for a systematic investigation of this problem, through a pertinent set of abstractions and analytical tools, that will provide all the fundamental insights and the necessary control policies. In addition, the developed policies must be kept sufficiently simple so that they are eventually implementable in a computationally efficient and robust manner. 

The considered project has contributed substantially towards the development of a methodological base for the support of effective and efficient traffic management in the context of the targeted applications, along the lines that were outlined in the previous paragraphs. A more specific enumeration of the project contributions is as follows:

1) It has provided a profound investigation of the problem of liveness preservation for the considered traffic systems, and it has identified some important factors that impact this problem and its complexity. Furthermore, it has developed liveness-enforcing supervisors (LES) that are efficiently implementable in the context of the targeted applications, and, at the same time, do not impose any severe unnecessary restriction to the underlying traffic.

2) It has integrated the derives LES with an additional control layer that ensures the expediency of the generated traffic, and its ability to adapt to a dynamic generation of the served transport requests and possibly other operational contingencies.

3) It has demonstrated and assessed the operational efficacy of the derived policies by simulating their implementation in (i) the control of some flexibly automated industrial operations, and (ii) the control of the qubit traffic that takes place in the context of quantum computing. The last task was performed in collaboration with a research group at the Georgia Tech Research Institute that develops a high-fidelity simulator of a quantum computer. 

On the educational side, the project has engaged three graduate (Ph.D. level) students as Graduate Research Assistants. Two of these students have already defended Ph.D. theses on problems formulated and addressed by the project, while the third one has developed a Ph.D. thesis proposal based on some of the project research themes.

Finally, all the derived results have been published extensively in a series of journal and conference publications.
